citeinfo.title: Real-time and Historical Marine Meteorological Data from NOAA's National Data Buoy Center (NDBC)

descript.abstract:
NOAA's National Data Buoy Center offers real-time and historical data from its 114 moored buoys and C-MAN (Coastal-Marine Automated Network) stations. Data is transmitted hourly via the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites (GOES).
All stations measure wind speed and direction, wind gust, barometric pressure and air temperature. All buoys and some C-MAN stations measure sea surface temperature, wave height, and wave period. Monthly and annual climatic summary tables are available.
Stations are located throughout U.S. coastal waters including U.S. Atlantic coast, U.S. Pacific coast, Gulf of Alaska, Bering Sea, Gulf of Mexico, Great Lakes and Hawaiian Islands. Some stations are also located in the western equatorial Pacific.
Real-time data is available hourly. After several days, data is quality-controlled and appended to daily data files. An archive of monthly data may also be accessed. The following types of quality-controlled data are available: standard meteorological data, acoustic Doppler current profiler (ADCP) data, continuous winds data, spectral wave density data, spectral wave direction data, water level data, and surface ocean current data.
Data is available through NDBC's WWW server using the station locator map or the station ID list and search: http://seaboard.ndbc.noaa.gov
Telnet, FTP and BBS service is also available:
"telnet://seaboard.ndbc.noaa.gov"
Anonymous FTP: ftp://seaboard.ndbc.noaa.gov
and give email address as the password
BBS phone number: 601-688-7938 modem settings: 8 data bits, no parity, and 1 stop bit, up to 28.8 Kbps
[This summary was derived from the NDBC WWW pages and Earth System Monitor Vol. 5, No. 4, June 1995.]
